> Just a tidbit of programming knowledge of stuff relating to the chain
> lightning, for those who care -- basically, the chain lightning code
*does*
> get horribly inefficient because of the way it works.  Basically, you get
a
> roughly n^2 (n-squared) processing time value, because each lightning
> object checks each possible enemy to see where it should head next,
> etc.  Thus, shooting it out when there are, say, 15 total characters on
the
> screen means a processing "cost" of around 225; bump that up to 50
> characters and you're up to 2500; move that up to 150 characters and
you're
> at 22500 -- 100x more processing time than with 15 characters.
>
> Of course, on fast systems (remember, Gladiator was programmed to run on a
> 286 or 386, so a p3 or p4 system is really fast for it!) plus enough real
> memory to keep everything local (without swapping to the hard drive or
> page-switching), that won't really matter, since even a heavily-bogged
down
> Gladiator is still only taking up 10-20% of your computer's efforts.
>
> --Tom
>
> At 01:18 PM 6/25/2001, you wrote:
> >The algorithm they are using is likely inefficient and has a very high
> >running cost, although it would have to be extreemely high cost and
> >extreemely inefficient to choke a 1GHz with only a handful (10-20) of
> >opponents.
> >There's any number of reasons why its inefficient, the only people that
know
> >anything about it are the programmers that wrote it :)
> >
> >However if the Forgotten Sages released the code for just the routine
chain
> >lightning uses we should be able to improve it.
